natural problem: How many multiples of 6 are greater than -25, but less than 25?
natural solution: To find out how many multiples there are that fit this description, first we find all the positive multiples, which are 6, 12, 18, and 24. Since 30 is greater than 25, it doesn't match the description and we now know that there are 4 positive multiples of 6 that are less than 25.

Because the limits for negative multiples are the same as the limits for positive multiples, we can figure out that the only negative multiples that are greater than -25 are -6, -12, -18, and -24. Four positive multiples, four negative multiples, and zero (because $6 \cdot 0=0$) means that there are $\boxed{9 \text{ multiples}}$ that will work.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: int
shows  "{n. n > -25 \<and> n < 25 \<and> 6 dvd n} = {n. -4 < n \<and> n < 4}"
using assms by (auto simp: dvd_def)
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many multiples of 6 are greater than -25, but less than 25? The final Answer is 9 \text{ multiples}
 ### Proof
 To find out how many multiples there are that fit this description, first we find all the positive multiples, which are 6, 12, 18, and 24. Since 30 is greater than 25, it doesn't match the description and we now know that there are 4 positive multiples of 6 that are less than 25.
 Because the limits for negative multiples are the same as the limits for positive multiples, we can figure out that the only negative multiples that are greater than -25 are -6, -12, -18, and -24. Four positive multiples, four negative multiples, and zero (because $6 \cdot 0=0$) means that there are $\boxed{9 \text{ multiples}}$ that will work.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: int
shows  "{n. n > -25 \<and> n < 25 \<and> 6 dvd n} = {n. -4 < n \<and> n < 4}"
using assms by (auto simp: dvd_def)
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: The set of all integers $n$ that are greater than $-25$, less than $25$, and divisible by $6$ is the same as the set of all integers $n$ that are greater than $-4$ and less than $4$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes multiples :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "multiples = {x. x mod 6 = 0}"
shows  "card {x \<in> multiples. -25 < x \<and> x < 25} = 9"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

Four positive multiples, four negative multiples, and zero (because $6 \cdot 0=0$) means that there are $\boxed{9 \text{ multiples}}$ that will work.
 *)

fixes multiples :: "int set"

shows  "card {x \<in> multiples. -25 < x \<and> x < 25} = 9"
